content: i like the cover picture a lot XD
Updated the first constraint, which previously said "1 < [[N]] 100," (< should be ≤, missing second ≤ sign, and the upper limit is way below 100).

After doing it, and asked some other users, I take the liberty to change the difficulty to "Medium". It can be really easy in languages with an eval() function, but a little harder with others. And I think it's better for users to solve easily a medium puzzle than to have an hard time on a easy one. ;)

Oh is it true that I'm the first to solve it? In java, and I didn't use a eval().
My implementation error is not caught in the clear testcases, but was caught in online Test 4:
I implemented "+-" having higher precedence than "*/".
I think a related test case is expected.

Nice puzzle!

And for this puzzle be classified as easy, I expect the problem description having "You would prefer a language having built-in eval() for this puzzle to be 'easy'.".

Thanks alze, Klemek & ToshiTuringMachineIl for the approval, and every one who took the time to look at this puzzle.
For the record, it is based on a real exercise of my 13yo son's math book.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: stub is not valid for bash. last line is not readable (It is not your fault. but cutting last line at character = is a real bash challenge....)

despite this, it is an original challenge, and nobody will solve it using bash, yuh ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I know I could have used the builtin eval function but the good old shunting yard worked like a charm, I had fun with this puzzle.

EDIT: I really like the idea, could there be more chapters with increasing difficulty ? Like an unknown variable, a more complex right side, other equalities like ">=" or even more sets of parenthesis. Something that pushes the player to build his own interpreter.

Typo: "unknwon"

There always seems to be missing a single set of parenthesis. Can this be added to the statement?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice, it pushed me to create a Java version of the eval() function, that hopefully will be handy in the future

Like the puzzle!
In the Input it says N but in the code there is n so I change the code to be N.

That's right, you will need to use an eval() function somehow. To choose the difficulty I assumed that most developpers know a langage that can do that.

I changed validator 4.

There is a typo in the last case of validator 4 (no need for parenthesis)
Also, I feel like the difficulty of the puzzle depends a bit on whether the language has an out of the box eval function or not.

Thanks. 
I found out that java has its own eval() equivalent with javax.script.ScriptEngine class
Well without an eval() function it must be a tough challenge
